newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bavaria's Stoiber says EMU criteria must be met.
newsitem.headline: Bavaria's Stoiber says EMU criteria must be met.

text.p: Bavarian premier Edmund Stoiber on Saturday kept up pressure to delay the launch of European economic and monetary union (EMU) if potential members fail to meet the entry criteria.
"If Germany and France miss the criteria, then a currency union at the planned time is not possible," Stoiber told the Bild daily in an interview.

Stoiber, a senior member of the conservative Christian Social Union (CSU) party which forms part of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling coalition, said the financial criteria for potential EMU members must be strictly interpreted.

He also repeated a plan he floated earlier this week, which would postpone the fixing of exchange rates among European currencies from 1999 until 2001 but still allow the new euro coins and notes to be introduced as planned in 2002.
"The years 1998 and 1999 would then be used as additional trial years to meet the criteria credibly," he said.
The Maastricht Treaty, which lays down the ground rules for the project, states that EMU members will be selected on the basis of financial data for 1997.

The German government has repeatedly stressed it is not considering any change to the current timetable. It has vowed to hit the Maastricht budget deficit goal of three percent of gross domestic product both this year and in 1998.
